This was my first in one of Stephen Grider course, and I really like his approach to teaching. He give practical real word advice on how to use vue and gives very clear explanation. Not only did I learn about vue, I learned a bit of ES6 and how to implement a login system. After going through his course I was able to build my vue app right away, and come back to reference his code on github.

I would love to see another course on this topic such Advance Vue js, because I would buy it right away.

After learning vue and building out my project, I also bought 3 more courses from Stephen Grider since I enjoyed his teaching style.

Would recommend to a friend!

results.content:
Ah, just finished the course, 5 star easily, and I must admit, I learned a lot ( so is the expectation from Stephen's courses). Coming with no prior vue experience, i did understand quite a lot.  Those who come from Angular ( like me ) or from React, everyone has got something here. From the ng-* kind of directives, routerLink, routerOutlet etc, we feel there is a lot of similarity. And for those coming from React, the mapStateToProps, mapDispatchToProps, redux , everything will seem familiar as its more or less banging on the same concepts. 

The only thing that i wish was, if there is more examples added on later, and things like Forms, Validations, custom authentication, authorization etc which wasn't covered in it along with topics like Testing, some CRUD operations at least in a firebase etc.  ( May be an advanced course which covers this! ). 

For an overall understanding of the Vue, i highly recommend anyone to take a dive and am sure, the money will be worth! Crystal clear concepts, ample diagrams, conceptual cracking, and examples backing them at a decent pace.  

Wish he was my college professor! I wudnt have to struggle to get a pass :)  His engaging lectures would have given me  a top grade .

"You and I will be learning a lot, and as he says, don't sweat it! "

results.content:
Another great course from Stephen. I've tried another Vue course before, but I found it incredibly dull and difficult to get through. That wasn't the case here. I enjoyed the various apps that we created throughout the course, though I think some people would benefit from additional exercises, of which there were only a small handful.

Now that I've completed the course, I feel confident that I could use Vue for some fairly complicated purposes, and I look forward to purchasing more of Stephen's courses in the future.

results.content:
As always, Stephen Grider presents an amazing resource. If you're completely new, it's a great way to get your feet wet into something new and challenging.  He goes through material at a slow enough pace to comprehend, breaks things up into bite-size pieces, and continually reminds students that it's okay if they don't understand something.

If you aren't a beginner, I find his courses very easy to go through a brisk pace if you just want to make sure you understand what's going on. 

His code examples are available on GitHub which is invaluable when you make a typo and are having trouble tracking it down.

results.content:
I thought the course was well put together. Although, I encountered  a major problem, because I was using the Edge browser, with the first project.  I asked a question which was never answered regarding CORS. I did solve my issue, but nobody answered my question and I really wanted to see how the instructor solves the issue.

Also there was an issue with one of the exercises (menu exerise). I had the correct logic and the everything worked, but an error was given. I probably spend a day looking at why the exercise failed.

All that aside, the course was very good. I like the fact the each lesson was fairly short, unlike some instructors that seem to have 30-40 minute lessons.

results.content: Stephen has made a truly awesome course here.  I am fairly new to HTML, CSS, and most importantly JavaScript and he made it very easy to understand. I do want to preface this with my knowledge level though which I think played a great role in how great this course was to me. Most of my career has been in the IT Operations/Infrastructure field and most recently implementing DevOps practices with a high performing development team so I was not completely brand new to the technologies. It was not so basic that it was boring for me but also not so high level that I was completely lost.  It was just the right amount. Started to get a little into promises at the end which was a little above what I knew but it gave me a good hint of what to dig a little deeper into.  Thanks for a great course Stephen!

results.content:
Good course with very good explanations, as always. Stephen never disappoints in that regard it seems. Coming from React this was a very good introduction into Vue.

A little criticism & suggestions:

Lack of notes / answers regarding some API issues will slow down beginners considerably. As this course is not focusing in depth on public API's & networking, it's only natural to make sure there is as little issues as possible for students in that regard, so they can focus on the topic. 

Youtube quota limit for one, which will fill very fast with requests happening per character typed. I would suggest refactoring to use "Search" button with v-on:submit. That way a student will be able to through that app in one day without hitting that wall. Seemed to me to be the natural solution for that issue and also more "real world" friendly. Not even Youtube itself have search per character typed. 

Another is imgur API acting funny when trying to allow the app, responding with "Unauthorized". One of those issues, that weirdly KIND OF fixes itself after messing around with it for a few minutes. Still not sure what fixed it in the end and why, but it did occur every day.

Some finishing touches for the image app would be welcome. Little things like not displaying upload box when logged out (was added for front page, but not for "/upload"). Making sure fetching images does not fire when not logged in. A little more conditional styling that plays together with using Vue, like for example a loader when uploading images.

With those handled and considering this as an introductory course into Vue, it's easily 5 stars.

results.content: Yet another great course from Stephen.  I've taken several of his courses, and he's definitely my favorite Udemy teacher.  This course is on the shorter end, so it's not what you could call comprehensive, but he hits all of the main aspects that will get you up and running with Vue -- components, directives, state management with Vuex, routing with Vue Router.  He even adds in useful things that aren't Vue-specific, such as OAuth and uploading images.  I definitely recommend this course if you want to understand Vue fundamentals but don't want to spend 20+ hours on a course.

results.content:
This was a good course. I enjoy the explanations and I enjoy seeing the work done in front of me whilst I can copy. This way of learning works, but the real learning comes from when you build something on your own and can't remember exactly what you were taught but know you were taught how to do what you want so you can then look it up or rewatch.

One thing I would say, however, is that I was hoping for a touch more coverage; v-model and mixins spring to mind. That said, if I already know about them, why am I mentioning them?

Overall, a great course, and the first one I've ever actually finished on Udemy.

My thanks.

results.content:
I have to be honest, I wasn't overly impressed with the course, it feels incomplete. I also felt this way after the React-Native course I took from Stephen.

I would have at the bare minimum expected him to cover building a project for production and deploying it. It also would have been nice if he covered making our apps responsive in Vue.

Those are two things I would consider essential aspects of building a web app. I personally have the knowledge to do both of those tasks, but it's a disservice to newer students to have them build something like this and not cover deployment.

Many students are doing these projects so they have something to demonstrate to friends/family/employers. The topics he did cover however he explained at an acceptable level so I do feel 3 stars is appropriate. If he was to ever come back and add to the course to make it feel more complete I would likely change my score.

- Bien que comprenant l'anglais afin d'être sûr de bien comprendre j'aime pouvoir suivre avec les sous titres (même en anglais) mais quand on voit la qualité de ceux ci*  on se demande comment les déficients auditifs font pour suivre ce cours même dans leur langue. (*exemple parmi beaucoup d'autres VUE CLI est transcrit en UCLA).
- Pour suivre la section 5 l'inscription à l'api d'imgur ne peut se faire sans donner son numéro de téléphone et je ne souhaite pas donner des données personnels à n'importe quel service et encore moins prendre le risque d'être spammer sur ce media.
Le cours devrait pouvoir être autonome.

Bien que ce cours m’ait été recommandé par un pro je suis très déçus. Quelque soit les qualités pédagogiques du formateur, je ne trouve pas le produit global professionnel. Je regrette mon achat.

The content is good as per Stephen's usual standards, but for an "essentials" course that is supposed to be brief and to the point I find he spends way too much time explaining extremely basic/obvious/not-super-relevant things instead of getting into the nitty gritty of what Vue actually is and what sets it apart from other JS frameworks. Update: OK, further ahead in the course things really pick up pace.

I wanted a quick intro to Vue and this course fit the bill perfectly.  You are exposed to a lot of Vue in this course, but the pace is quite fast and explanations, while clear and too the point, aren't always in depth.  That was fine with me, as that is what I was looking for, but for a deep understanding of the topic, you'll need to do some extra homework/reading.

One thing I would like to see is maybe some more exercises and coding challenges.

That said, when you finish the course you'll be well able to write your own components and Vue applications.

One other thing to note, and it is mentioned in the course overview, but you need to take heed: this isn't a Javascript course.  You need to have a good understanding of Javascript syntax and of some of its newer features.  Some of the more esoteric syntax is explained, but by and large it is expected that you know JS.
results.content_html:
I wanted a quick intro to Vue and this course fit the bill perfectly. You are exposed to a lot of Vue in this course, but the pace is quite fast and explanations, while clear and too the point, aren't always in depth. That was fine with me, as that is what I was looking for, but for a deep understanding of the topic, you'll need to do some extra homework/reading.

One thing I would like to see is maybe some more exercises and coding challenges.

That said, when you finish the course you'll be well able to write your own components and Vue applications.

One other thing to note, and it is mentioned in the course overview, but you need to take heed: this isn't a Javascript course. You need to have a good understanding of Javascript syntax and of some of its newer features. Some of the more esoteric syntax is explained, but by and large it is expected that you know JS.

results.content:
Very well presented introduction to Vue.js.  It is not meant to be a comprehensive overview, so you will need to do a follow up course to dive deeper into Vue.js capabilities and features.

The course could benefit from additional coverage of using and building filters as well as building and deploying to production. There is not much mention of webpack and loaders, Babel or the Vue cli.  I would also like more coverage of lazy loading routes and how to do more with the build configuration as well as adding 3rd party assets such as images and CSS to your projects locally instead of pulling them in from CDNs.

Overall a very nice introduction to Vue.js.

results.content: Stephen does not disappoint! This was the first course of his that I've taken and I was immediately impressed by his ability to gradually layer concept complexity at the expense of the time taken demonstrating alternate techniques that would later be overwritten. His explanations highlight lessons learned over years of experience, and the use of multiple conceptual diagrams truly speaks to his ability to compartmentalize and simplify relationships for his audience. Each lesson has a singular focus, made evident by a lack of bookmarks throughout the course, limiting time wasted when reviewing the more difficult concepts. Lastly, the development tools are all nicely packaged and easily deployed eliminating tooling headaches.
